Award.AbstractNarration:
In this proposal, the PI proposes to study geometric problems that are inspired from physics, especially equations that are relevant to string theory and general relativity.

An important set of nonlinear equations appeared in Heterotic string theory as a coupled system of Einstein and Yang Mills over a complex manifold. We propose to solve this system. We expect to use this system to understand structures of higher dimensional manifolds. Intrinsic metrics on moduli space of complex structures and curves of higher genus on Calabi-Yau manifolds play a very important role in algebraic geometry and string theory, we expect to study their properties in detail. We would like to generalize some of our previous works on moduli space of Rieman surfaces to higher dimension. In general relativity, we shall continue to study the definition of quasi-local mass and their properties.

The interaction between theoretical physics and mathematics have been extremely fruitful in the past quarter of century. This proposal is part of this interaction. While the works will serve the physics community, we are confident that the outcome of this research will give insights that will lead to better understanding of geometry .

POR.DRECONTENT:
We made a breakthrough in finding the right definition of quasilocal mass, linear momentum,  center of mass, and angular momentum in general relativity. With deep analysis, we proved the properties of these quantities that are required for the physical consideration. This problem has been very subtle in general relativity and was proposed by Penrose about forty years ago. A good understanding of the concept is a necessary step towards understanding of our large-scale universe such as gravitational radiation and the gravitational energy stored in the galaxies

In the other direction, in an effort to understand several important concepts in string theory, we made significant progress in computing the period integral, which like the number Pi, holds secrets for many questions in different branches of mathematics and physics. In particular, it can reveal secrets for hidden dimensions of our universe, which has a huge effect on the physics that we experience. At the same time, it contains answers to some of the most intricate problems in classical and modern geometry.

We also developed new important methods and techniques in graph theory, which is on the boundary between pure and applied math, and applies to big data analysis, image processing, etc, in novel ways, as well as to number theory. 

This grant supported more than ten students and postdoctoral fellows, some of whom are becoming young experts in their fields. We also used it to support weekly Differential Geometry and Special Geometry seminars, and to support a large number of visitors, with whom we collaborated on important and timely projects.

In summary, this grant helped to maintain a delicate mixture of experts in different areas in order to attack some of the most important problems in geometry and related areas. In mathematics we often need exactly the right people to do certain things. Much of the progress would not be possible without such teamwork.
